did.unittitle: Geneva Academy Board of Trustees records

bioghist.p: The town of Geneva, Kansas, was founded by free-state men in the summer of 1857. The idea of the settlement began with ambition, but the establishment of and building a large town never came to fruition; less than one fourth of the projected 300 families engaged to settle came. Originally, it had been decided to build a large structure and found a non-sectarian college and academy, but through the lack of money and settlement the college was not built, though an academy later took its place. The school had been established in 1866 under charge of the Neosho Presbytery.

scopecontent.p: This collection is of the Geneva Academy Board of Trustees minutes and financial records, 1865-1913. Minutes are from 1865-1913, with gaps. Minutes include the constitution and by-laws of the Board of Trustees; plans for a building for the academy; decisions about tuition, school rules, and leasing of rooms and records of actions brought in court related to the occupancy rights to the building (1873-1875). The volume also includes some financial accounting of the Academy. Accounts from 1858-1860 may belong to L. L. Northrup, G. S. Northrup, or the Union Settlement Company, but provenance is unclear.
